Legal_Issue: Whether trademark rights can be claimed for an expired patent's design and term
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence that 'BARB TIE' was used in Canada to identify the plaintiff's product; oval shape was part of expired patent's preferred embodiment
Decision_Outcome: Plaintiff cannot claim trademark rights for the oval shape or 'BARB TIE'
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to establish valid trademark use
Legal_Rule: Expired patents cannot be extended via trademark claims if it restricts public use of the invention; trademark requires visible association with goods
Procedural_Issue: Appropriateness of granting summary judgment on trademark claims
Grounds_for_Claim: Claim of trademark rights in product shape and name post-patent expiration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use (or lack thereof) of 'BARB TIE' in Canadian market; patent documentation regarding oval shape
Applicant_Challenge: Plaintiff's attempt to assert trademark rights after patent expiry
Legal_Rule_Source: Canadian case law and statutes on trademark and patent law
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, patent records, market usage data
Remedy_Requested: Recognition of trademark rights, injunctive relief
Legal_Provision_Cited: Relevant sections of the Trademarks Act and Patent Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Trademark claim attempts to extend expired patent monopoly
Governing_Rule: Common law principles on exhaustion of patent rights and trademark distinctiveness
